reviewText: the main reason I bought this was for the bonus feature about Audie Murphy!!  It clearly states on the advertisement that it was included!!  It has a place for the Bonus feature " Medal of Honor, The Audie Murphy Story" but it is missing!! Now none of the 3 DVD's talk about the bonus feature in them!!  They list all of the movies that are on each DVD but not a one list the Bonus Feature that is advertised on the cover of the Box that contains them!! Yet, the box clearly states that this set contains the Bonus Feature!!  Maybe it was done that way to sale it I don't know but, to me it is just wrong to list something then not include it!! Now if Amazon will get me the missing Bonus feature then maybe I will change my rating but for now I would advise against buying this item unless you don't care about getting the bonus feature!! But then maybe Amazon needs to change how this item is advertised and let people know that the bonus feature is not included in the box set!!

reviewText: With the notoriety over the series being yanked by NBC due to a grandstanding politician complaining about "Whispering Smith's" violence I was especially intersted to see what all the fuss was about.  As far as the mayhem quotient, it's normal for a late '50s/early '60s TV western.  Some good, nicely staged gunplay and stunts are scattered throughout.  So kudos to Timeless Media Group for releasing "Whispering Smith" a half century later.  The print and audio quality are excellent.  The running time appears to be full length, not annoyingly abbreviated like TMG's other western titles from Revue/Universal, "Laredo" and "Wagon Train." (Why, oh why, doesn't TMG go the extra mile and provide consumers the full-length prints on "Laredo" and "Wagon Train?!")  How nice it is to see Universal Studios' Denver Street in all its glory.  (A couple years later it became Medicine Bow for "The Virginian.")  Also nice that the brief title card and music fanfare at the midshow commercial break position is maintained.  Two gripes on "Whispering Smith" from TMG: 1) It's not necessary to edit the Revue Productions title card and fanfare at the tail of the end titles, so why does TMG do this?!  To this user it's maddening.  2) No bonus tracks.  We all know star Audie Murphy's dead, but surely TMG could have rounded up a few guest stars, an assistant director, publicist or someone similar with first hand knowledge of the show's production to enlighten viewers and make this a really special DVD.  But, go ahead and buy "Whispering Smith."  I hope you enjoy viewing the episodes as much as I did.

Title: N/A

reviewText: I've always admired Audie Murphy and bougth this mostly forgotten series sight unseen.  I have read that Murphy didn't like doing this show but I didn't see any hint of that.  This series was filmed in around 1959 and unknown to Murphy his career was about to hit a down turn.  after this he appeared in just one more major motion piture- "The Unforgivin" with Burt Landcaster.  After that, dispite a fine porformace, he went on to only make B-movies of very low quality.Murphy is in fine form in this show, he had matured out of his "kid" look.  This is basicly a detective show in an old west town.  I think that it was a lost opportunty that Jack Webb or someone never developed a modern detective show for Audie Murphy in the 60's.  As a part-time lawman and a conservative icon he would have been perfect.One thing that I enjoy about this show is that it was a half hour series and makes for good repeated viewing, more so than hour long dvd collections, IMO.This set is essential to any Audie Murphy collection.  It would also be nice to have  on dvd "The Kid From Texas" his first starring role western, and some of his non westerns, like "The World In My Corner" his boxing movie.
summary: Makes You Think of What His Later Career Could Have Been

reviewText: While it may seem a little corny by contemporary standards, never-the-less it is fun to watch.  Whispering Smith tries never to shoot to kill and usually brings in the culprit.  Audie Murphy is competent in the role and obviously knows how to handle a gun.  The supporting actors are equally competent.  The picture quality is excellent and the sound is good.Black and white was the TV of the 50's, so this is a good way to show your grandchildren what you watched when you were their age. I vaguely remember this particular series, but it is representative of the western series of the time - Hop-along Cassidy, Annie Oakley, The Lone Ranger, Roy Rogers, Gene Autry, etc.  It's clean family fun.  The bad guys get their comeuppances, no blood spurting, not even a bullet hole.  It was a simpler time in America, when even the cities were safer and the people were nicer.So, do what we do.  Each week for 25 weeks on Tuesday night (pick whatever night works for you) after dinner, pop up some corn. Sit down with the family, or some friends and watch a half hour of Whispering Smith.  Discover, or relive, a little bit of that simpler time.
summary: Fun to watch -  worth the money!

reviewText: Yep, this was an obscure western series from 1959-60, but it waited until late in the 1960-61 season when it finally made its debut, because of one problem after another. First, Guy Mitchell, the singer-actor who played George Romack, broke his shoulder falling from a horse, therby halting production for several weeks, enabling Audie Murphy to do a movie. Sam Buffington, who played Smith and Romack's boss Capt. John Richards comitted suicide in May 1960, guess he wasn't happy doing the series. When Whispering Smith did make it to the air in May 1961, it was met with low ratings, critical dismissal, and lambasted by politicians in a Senate subcommittee on TV violence, so this show met its demise in September 1961, leaving five episodes unaired.But now, its all here in this 3-DVD collection from TMG, the quality is quite good, similar their earlier releases of other classic shows like Riverbaot, The Tall Man, etc. under license from NBC Universal, and Audie Murphy excels in the title role as a Denver Police detective. Mitchell does a fine job as Romack, for their was good chemistry between these characters. It is not quite as violent as you would think, for there is way more violence in TV and movies today then there was then. So pick up a copy of this 'lost' video sagebrush saga, and see for yourself what this show was all about.
summary: The Show That Waited Forever To Be Aired!

reviewText: Enjoyable trip through Audie Murphy's career as a TV western hero. Few people realize how talented Audie was as an actor. In these episodes Audie stands out just by the majesty of his presence on screen. He possesses a strength of character that adds dignity to every role he plays, even in these sometimes banal stories. He is always worth watching. For further proof of his talent I recommend his performance in "The Quiet American," also available from Amazon.Com.

reviewText: Even though I was a fan of Western TV shows and movies throughout the late 50's and mid-60's, I do not recall Whispering Smith. I was a fan of Audie Murphy though, until his early tragic death in 1971. But, I must say, I find this western series a solid 5 stars. Mostly more for its fantastic scripts, and realism played into the characters seen in this too short series. Hard to believe this series was castigated for its extreme violence in 1961. I find it about on par with the violence in Have Gun Will Travel, and yet HGWT lasted a long time. If you like early westerns like HGWT, Wanted: Dead or Alive, The Rifleman and such, you will enjoy this series. I watched it way too fast, with no more episodes to look forward to. Guess I will watch it again!

reviewText: I bought this series sight unseen and am pretty happy I did.This is not a great western series but a good one.Audie Murphy was a World War II hero in real life receiving many medals and honours. This is reflected in a documentary on his life in the service put on this DVD as an extra bonus. There were only 20 episodes aired but here we have an extra 5 that were not. Audie Murphy was in plenty of westerns during the fifties and early sixties and this was his only TV series. Whispering Smith was the first detective of the West and used up to date police methods to catch the villains. I don't remember why they called him" whispering" but here there is plenty of gunplay and action. A entertaining western on the whole. Guy Mitchell who was a popular singing star in the fifties plays whispering Smith's partner. This show is a rare beast that hardly anybody remembers. It only ran for one season and was delayed from airing from 1959 to 1961 as Guy Mitchell broke his shoulder and production of the show was halted. There are not a lot of well known guest stars here. Just a few like Robert Redford, Clu  Gulager who played Deputy Ryker on "The Virgininan", Richard Chamberlain who played in "Dr Kildare" and James Best who was Sheriff Roscoe T Coltrane on the TV series "The Dukes of Hazzard".
summary: Not with a whisper, but a bang.

reviewText: I bought this on a whim for $9.99 at Half Price Books. Very Good film quaility, good audio. The DVD's come in 3 black slim line case, each with a 2 - 3 three line synopsis of each episode on the back. None of the disc's are marked 1,2,3, nor is the front or back cover sleeve on the case numbered.Number 1,2,3, appears on the thin edge of the case sleeve liner. Unfortunately the box the the three cases slides into is so tight fitting the cases cannot be pulled out of the box. You have to open the end flap and push them out.The episode titles that appear on the main menu page are very hard to read. Its a weird written font. I watched them on a 19" TV, maybe a larger TV would be better?? The series only ran one season with 26 episodes. The set I bought has all 26(twenty Six) episodes plus the Audy Murphy Story. FOr some reason Amazon says 25 episodes.Its nice to see all the old actors and actresses that are long gone....

reviewText: Hi All,Being the Audie Murphy fan that I am. I try to get my hands on anything I haven't seen.I rate this series as 4(3.5) stars. There is no 3.5 stars category. There are audio and video issues here. So if you are looking to get the same audio and video quality of the Audie Murphy Special Collection offered by Amazon(see my separate review)for Sierra an (3) three other Audie greats, Whispering Smith The Complete TV series will not be the same quality. However, as stated earlier if you love Audie this won't and should not stop you from getting footage few have seen and now enjoy since the early 60's on NBC. There is also an interesting sound background the original producers used to fill in the scenes. They used a trombone (semi solo) which personally I would not have chosen but considering the lack of background music for TV developed to that point in time it is somewhat understandable.  I would recommend Audie in Whispering Smith, but only with the caveats previously mentioned above. Hope this helps.Blessings,Phil
summary: Audie on a TV Series Pretty Darn Good 3.5 Stars

reviewText: Amazon and the package promotes this being the complete series. It is not. They filmed 26 episodes and only 25 are included. Talk about a big mistake! However, this was considered a Holy Grail of TV Westerns for many years so I for one am thankful of the 25. On a scale of one to ten, I would give the picture quality a 9 or 9.5. They are not remastered, but the transfers are for the most part clean. Whispering Smith was a detective on the Denver, Colorado Police Department in the 1870s. This show took case histories from Smith's adventures. George Romack was Smith's partner and John Richards was the police chief. The series was filmed in 1959 but never televised until 1961. Rumor has it that the show got pulled after people complained it was too violent. I doubt that. The 26 episodes were already in the can more than a year and a half before they were televised and by that time Murphy was filming a number of action westerns for the big screen. Why would he want to return to television? Amazon's asking price is a bargain for this series.

reviewText: Audie Murphy was a bona fide hero, the most decorated soldier of World War II, although he appeared to be underage, years after the war, with a less than baritone voice.  He was in life an expert marksman, according to his sister.  Being from Texas he surely knew about horses and cattle.  In short, he was just about everything John Wayne was not--and yet Murphy never quite fit the role of a western movie hero.Here he is cast as a lawman, and one is hard pressed to accept this.  The plots are not much, the usual bad guys who are thwarted by the good guys.  The acting is unremarkable.  No attempt is made toward realism.  One episode will about cover it for the rest.  It's obvious that Murphy was hired as an actor, not on his thespian talent, but because of the role he played in real life.In short, this is not much more that a curiosity.  And yet, I am still in awe of the star and what he did on another field of endeavor.
summary: A hero somehow out of his element
